page.title: 12Clifton Airfield
page.content: Clifton Airfield during the war was a non_operational training airfield co_operational between the Royal Air Force and the Army. Lysanders,used to land in France to drop off agents, were kept there. Soldiers and air-men were billeted on local people for a guinea a week. After the war Halifax Bomber Aircraft were landed on the airfield and then broken up by gangs of men. The aeroplanes were stacked into a heap about 12 metres high and 90 metres long on the edge of the airfield. At the moment there is an attempt being made by a group of enthusiasts to find enough parts to rebuild just one Halifax Bomber. Mr and Mrs Leaf of Clifton Gate who have farmed here for 38 years told us of a farm road which was made of Halifax Bomber wings.The road is now buried beneath a hay field.
